Replace.Text: You have discovered Lost Ruins! Sending a Unit into the Ruins may uncover hidden secrets!

Row.Text: An unknown civilization has proven that the world is round!
{1_LeaderName} of {2_CivName} has proven that the world is round!
Your maps have proven that the world is round. Your ships gain [ICON_MOVEMENT] +1 Move.

+1 [ICON_PEACE] Faith for every 2 [ICON_CITIZEN] Citizens in the City.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Reduces [ICON_HAPPINESS_3] Religious Unrest, doubles Religious Pressure generated by Trade Routes, and generates +25% Religious Pressure.[NEWLINE]Nearby [ICON_RES_INCENSE] Incense: +1 [ICON_CULTURE] Culture, +1 [ICON_PEACE] Faith.[NEWLINE]Nearby [ICON_RES_JFD_SAFFRON] Saffron: +1 [ICON_CULTURE] Culture, +1 [ICON_PEACE] Faith.[NEWLINE]Nearby [ICON_RES_WINE] Wine: +1 [ICON_CULTURE] Culture, +1 [ICON_PEACE] Faith.

+1 [ICON_PEACE] Faith for every 2 [ICON_CITIZEN] Citizens in the City.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Reduces [ICON_HAPPINESS_3] Religious Unrest, doubles Religious Pressure generated by Trade Routes, and generates +25% Religious Pressure.[NEWLINE]Nearby [ICON_RES_AMBER] Amber: +1 [ICON_CULTURE] Culture, +1 [ICON_PEACE] Faith.[NEWLINE]Nearby [ICON_RES_INCENSE] Incense: +1 [ICON_CULTURE] Culture, +1 [ICON_PEACE] Faith.[NEWLINE]Nearby [ICON_RES_JFD_SAFFRON] Saffron: +1 [ICON_CULTURE] Culture, +1 [ICON_PEACE] Faith.[NEWLINE]Nearby [ICON_RES_WINE] Wine: +1 [ICON_CULTURE] Culture, +1 [ICON_PEACE] Faith.

+When any [ICON_INTERNATIONAL_TRADE] Trade Route originating here and targeting another Civ is completed, receive a [ICON_TOURISM] Tourism boost with the Civ based on your recent [ICON_CULTURE] Culture output.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Trade routes gain 50% range. +1 [ICON_GOLD] Gold to [ICON_INTERNATIONAL_TRADE] Trade Routes to or from City.[NEWLINE]Nearby [ICON_RES_JFD_GINGER] Ginger: +1 [ICON_FOOD] Food, +1 [ICON_PEACE] Faith.[NEWLINE]Nearby [ICON_RES_SPICES] Spices: +1 [ICON_FOOD] Food, +1 [ICON_PRODUCTION] Production.[NEWLINE]Nearby [ICON_RES_SUGAR] Sugar: +1 [ICON_FOOD] Food, +1 [ICON_GOLD] Gold.

The Bazaar is the Arabian unique building, replacing the Market. The Bazaar provides [ICON_GOLD] Gold and boosts Trade Route range. The Bazaar also boosts the yields of [ICON_RES_JFD_GINGER], [ICON_RES_SPICES] and [ICON_RES_SUGAR] Sugar.

Unique Indonesian Garden replacement. A [ICON_RES_CLOVES] Clove, [ICON_RES_PEPPER] Pepper, or [ICON_RES_NUTMEG] Nutmeg Resource will appear near or under this City when built.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]+25% [ICON_GREAT_PEOPLE] Great People generation in this City, and 20% of the City''s [ICON_PEACE] Faith is converted into [ICON_RESEARCH] Science every turn.[NEWLINE]Nearby [ICON_RES_CITRUS] Citrus: +1 [ICON_FOOD] Food, +1 [ICON_GOLD] Gold.[NEWLINE]Nearby [ICON_RES_COCOA] Cocoa: +1 [ICON_FOOD] Food, +1 [ICON_GOLD] Gold[NEWLINE]Nearby [ICON_RES_JFD_OPIUM] Opium: +1 [ICON_FOOD] Food, +1 [ICON_GOLD] Gold.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Unlike the Garden the Candi does not have to be built next to a River or Lake.

+1 [ICON_FOOD] Food on nearby Forest and Jungle tiles.[NEWLINE]Nearby [ICON_RES_JFD_OBSIDIAN] Obsidian: +1 [ICON_GOLD] Gold, +1 [ICON_PRODUCTION] Production.[NEWLINE]Nearby [ICON_RES_JFD_VANILLA] Vanilla: +1 [ICON_GOLD] Gold, +1 [ICON_FOOD] Food.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]City must have a workable Forest or Jungle tile in its borders.
Each source of [ICON_RES_JFD_RUBBER] Rubber and [ICON_RES_JFD_SULFUR] Sulphur worked by this City produce +1 [ICON_PRODUCTION] Production.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Requires 1 [ICON_RES_COAL] Coal.

The Factory is an Industrial-era building which greatly increases a city's [ICON_PRODUCTION] Production, especially if there is a nearby source of Rubber or Sulphur. The city must already possess a Workshop (or Longhouse). 1 [ICON_RES_COAL] Coal is consumed when a Factory is created.

Requires 1 [ICON_RES_COAL] Coal. +1 [ICON_PRODUCTION] Production for every 4 [ICON_CITIZEN] Citizens in the City. Each source of [ICON_RES_JFD_RUBBER] Rubber and [ICON_RES_JFD_SULFUR] Sulphur worked by this City produce +1 [ICON_PRODUCTION] Production.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]All Engineers Specialists in the City gain +2 [ICON_GOLD] Gold, and all Merchant Specialists in the City gain +2 [ICON_PRODUCTION] Production.

+20% [ICON_GREAT_PEOPLE] Great People generation in this City.[NEWLINE]Nearby [ICON_RES_CITRUS] Citrus: +1 [ICON_FOOD] Food, +1 [ICON_GOLD] Gold.[NEWLINE]Nearby [ICON_RES_COCOA] Cocoa: +1 [ICON_FOOD] Food, +1 [ICON_GOLD] Gold.[NEWLINE]Nearby [ICON_RES_JFD_OPIUM] Opium: +1 [ICON_FOOD] Food, +1 [ICON_GOLD] Gold.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]City must NOT be built next to a River or Lake. Cannot be built if City already has a Bath, and requires an Aqueduct in the City.

Each source of [ICON_RES_BANANA] Bananas, [ICON_RES_BISON] Bison, [ICON_RES_DEER] Deer, and [ICON_RES_WHEAT] Wheat worked by this City produce +1 [ICON_FOOD] Food.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Allows [ICON_FOOD] Food to be moved from this city along trade routes inside your civilization.

+1 [ICON_PRODUCTION] Production and +1 [ICON_FOOD] Food from all Forests and Jungles worked by this City.[NEWLINE]Nearby [ICON_RES_JFD_OBSIDIAN] Obsidian: +1 [ICON_GOLD] Gold, +1 [ICON_PRODUCTION] Production.[NEWLINE]Nearby [ICON_RES_JFD_VANILLA] Vanilla: +1 [ICON_GOLD] Gold, +1 [ICON_FOOD] Food.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]City must have a workable Forest or Jungle tile in its borders.

+1 [ICON_GOLD] Gold to [ICON_INTERNATIONAL_TRADE] Trade Routes to or from City.[NEWLINE]Nearby [ICON_RES_JFD_GINGER] Ginger: +1 [ICON_FOOD] Food, +1 [ICON_PEACE] Faith.[NEWLINE]Nearby [ICON_RES_SPICES] Spices: +1 [ICON_FOOD] Food, +1 [ICON_PRODUCTION] Production.[NEWLINE]Nearby [ICON_RES_SUGAR] Sugar: +1 [ICON_FOOD] Food, +1 [ICON_GOLD] Gold.

Markets increase the amount of [ICON_GOLD] Gold a city generates, and sources of [ICON_RES_JFD_GINGER] Ginger, [ICON_RES_SPICES] Spices and [ICON_RES_SUGAR] Sugar gain +1 [ICON_GOLD] and +1 [ICON_PRODUCTION] Production. Trade routes other players make to a city with a Market will generate an extra 1 [ICON_GOLD] Gold for the city owner and the trade route owner gains an additional 1 [ICON_GOLD] Gold for the trade route.
Each source of [ICON_RES_INCENSE] Incense, [ICON_RES_JFD_SAFFRON] Saffron, and [ICON_RES_WINE] Wine worked by this City produce +1 [ICON_PEACE] Faith and +1 [ICON_CULTURE] Culture.

Monasteries increase a city's [ICON_PEACE] Faith and [ICON_CULTURE] Culture output, especially if the city is near to improved Incense, Saffron, and/or Wine resources. Can only be built in cities following a religion with the Monasteries belief. Construct this building by purchasing it with [ICON_PEACE] Faith.

+1 [ICON_PRODUCTION] Production for every 2 [ICON_CITIZEN] Citizens in the City. All Engineers Specialists in the City gain +2 [ICON_GOLD] Gold, and all Merchant Specialists in the City gain +2 [ICON_PRODUCTION] Production. Each source of [ICON_RES_JFD_RUBBER] Rubber and [ICON_RES_JFD_SULFUR] Sulphur worked by this City produce +1 [ICON_PRODUCTION] Production.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Trade routes other players make to a city with a Steam Mill will generate an extra 3 [ICON_GOLD] Gold for the city owner and the trade route owner gains an additional 3 [ICON_GOLD] Gold for the trade route.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Nearby [ICON_RES_COAL] Coal: +3 [ICON_PRODUCTION] Production.

Reduces [ICON_HAPPINESS_3] Religious Unrest and generates +25% Religious Pressure.[NEWLINE]Nearby [ICON_RES_INCENSE] Incense: +1 [ICON_CULTURE] Culture, +1 [ICON_PEACE] Faith.[NEWLINE]Nearby [ICON_RES_JFD_SAFFRON] Saffron: +1 [ICON_CULTURE] Culture, +1 [ICON_PEACE] Faith.[NEWLINE]Nearby [ICON_RES_WINE] Wine: +1 [ICON_CULTURE] Culture, +1 [ICON_PEACE] Faith.

Reduces [ICON_HAPPINESS_3] Religious Unrest and generates +25% Religious Pressure.[NEWLINE]Nearby [ICON_RES_AMBER] Amber: +1 [ICON_CULTURE] Culture, +1 [ICON_PEACE] Faith.[NEWLINE]Nearby [ICON_RES_INCENSE] Incense: +1 [ICON_CULTURE] Culture, +1 [ICON_PEACE] Faith.[NEWLINE]Nearby [ICON_RES_JFD_SAFFRON] Saffron: +1 [ICON_CULTURE] Culture, +1 [ICON_PEACE] Faith.[NEWLINE]Nearby [ICON_RES_WINE] Wine: +1 [ICON_CULTURE] Culture, +1 [ICON_PEACE] Faith.
Each source of [ICON_RES_JFD_MAIZE] Maize and [ICON_RES_JFD_RICE] Rice worked by this City produce +1 [ICON_FOOD] Food.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]

A corporation is a company or group of people authorized to act as a single entity (legally a person) and recognized as such in law. Early incorporated entities were established by charter (i.e. by an ad hoc act granted by a monarch or passed by a parliament or legislature). Most jurisdictions now allow the creation of new corporations through registration. Corporations come in many different types but are usually divided by the law of the jurisdiction where they are chartered into two kinds: by whether or not they can issue stock, or by whether or not they are for profit.

Receive two [ICON_INTERNATIONAL_TRADE] Trade Routes. +3 [ICON_CULTURE] Culture and +3 [ICON_PEACE] Faith on all Monopoly Resources associated with Scented Fragrances. All Herbalists produce +3 [ICON_CULTURE] Culture and +3 [ICON_PEACE] Faith.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Remember that each Civilization may only found [COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]one[ENDCOLOR] Corporation, so make sure the benefits are applicable to your Victory Strategy!

Requires a Global Monopoly on [ICON_RES_PERFUME] Perfume, [ICON_RES_JFD_SAFFRON] Saffron, [ICON_RES_JFD_OPIUM] Opium, or [ICON_RES_JFD_VANILLA] Vanilla. [NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Receive a free Scented Fragrances Office in this City, and unlocks construction of Scented Fragrances Offices in owned Cities.

Resource Bonus: [ICON_RES_PERFUME] Perfume, [ICON_RES_JFD_SAFFRON] Saffron, [ICON_RES_JFD_OPIUM] Opium, or [ICON_RES_JFD_VANILLA] Vanilla gain additional [ICON_CULTURE] Culture and [ICON_PEACE] Faith.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Office Bonus: +3 [ICON_CULTURE] Culture and +3 [ICON_PEACE] Faith for every Global Franchise (up to your Franchise Limit).[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Trade Route Bonus: Trade Routes to foreign Cities with a Scented Fragrances Franchise produce +100% [ICON_RESEARCH] Science, and owned Trade Routes cannot be pillaged.

A corporation is a company or group of people authorized to act as a single entity (legally a person) and recognized as such in law. Early incorporated entities were established by charter (i.e. by an ad hoc act granted by a monarch or passed by a parliament or legislature). Most jurisdictions now allow the creation of new corporations through registration. Corporations come in many different types but are usually divided by the law of the jurisdiction where they are chartered into two kinds: by whether or not they can issue stock, or by whether or not they are for profit.

This building can only be constructed in Foreign Cities if you were the founder of Scented Fragrances. To construct this building in a foreign City, send a Trade Route from an owned City with a Scented Fragrances Office in it to a foreign City. When the Trade Route is complete, the building will automatically be constructed.
+1 [ICON_GOLD] Gold to all Monopoly Resources worked by this City that are associated with Scented Fragrances. Generates revenue for Scented Fragrances Offices in the founding Civilization's Cities.

A corporation is a company or group of people authorized to act as a single entity (legally a person) and recognized as such in law. Early incorporated entities were established by charter (i.e. by an ad hoc act granted by a monarch or passed by a parliament or legislature). Most jurisdictions now allow the creation of new corporations through registration. Corporations come in many different types but are usually divided by the law of the jurisdiction where they are chartered into two kinds: by whether or not they can issue stock, or by whether or not they are for profit.

When a [ICON_INTERNATIONAL_TRADE] Trade Route between a foreign City and this City completes, a Scented Fragrances Franchise is constructed in the foreign City.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Scented Fragrances cannot be sold or destroyed by the player, and increases the [ICON_CULTURE] Culture and [ICON_PEACE] Faith output of all Scented Fragrances Offices by +3.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]You cannot have more Franchises than the maximum of possible [ICON_INTERNATIONAL_TRADE] Trade Routes supported by your empire.

+20% [ICON_FOOD] Food stored after growth in this City. +3 [ICON_CULTURE] Culture and [ICON_PEACE] Faith for every Scented Fragrances Franchise (up to your Franchise Limit).[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Trade Routes to foreign Cities with a Scented Fragrances Franchise produce +33% [ICON_CULTURE] Culture and [ICON_PEACE] Faith.

Requires a Global Monopoly on [ICON_RES_GOLD] Gold, [ICON_RES_SILVER] Silver, [ICON_RES_GEMS] Gems, [ICON_RES_JFD_OBSIDIAN] Obsidian, [ICON_RES_PEARLS] Pearls, or [ICON_RES_JEWELRY] Jewelery.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Receive a free Civlized Jewelers Office in this City, and unlocks construction of Civlized Jewelers Offices in owned Cities.

Resource(s) Needed: [ICON_RES_GOLD] Gold, [ICON_RES_SILVER] Silver, [ICON_RES_GEMS] Gems, [ICON_RES_JFD_OBSIDIAN] Obsidian, [ICON_RES_PEARLS] Pearls, or [ICON_RES_JEWELRY] Jewelery.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Office Bonus: +5% [ICON_GREAT_PEOPLE] Great Person Rate for every Global Franchise (up to your Franchise Limit).[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Trade Route Bonus: Trade Routes to a foreign City with a Civilized Jewelers Franchise increases the origin City's [ICON_GOLD] Gold rate by +10%.

Requires a Global Monopoly on [ICON_RES_IRON] Iron, [ICON_RES_ALUMINUM] Aluminum, [ICON_RES_MARBLE] Marble, [ICON_RES_COPPER] Copper, [ICON_RES_JFD_MANUSCRIPTS] Manuscripts, or [ICON_RES_PORCELAIN] Porcelain. [NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Receive a free Firaxite Materials Office in this City, and unlocks construction of Firaxite Materials Offices in owned Cities.

Resource Bonus: [ICON_RES_IRON] Iron, [ICON_RES_ALUMINUM] Aluminum, [ICON_RES_MARBLE] Marble, [ICON_RES_COPPER] Copper, [ICON_RES_JFD_MANUSCRIPTS] Manuscripts, or [ICON_RES_PORCELAIN] Porcelain gain additional [ICON_RESEARCH] Science.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Office Bonus: +3 [ICON_RESEARCH] Science for every Global Franchise (up to your Franchise Limit).[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Trade Route Bonus: Trade Routes to foreign Cities with a Firaxite Materials Franchise produce +100% [ICON_RESEARCH] Science, and owned Trade Routes cannot be pillaged.

Replace.Text: You find a cache of supplies that boost the [ICON_PRODUCTION] Production of your nearest city!
You find ancient relics that accelerate your civilization's progress towards a [ICON_GOLDEN_AGE] Golden Age!
You find a nomadic tribe that wishes to join your Civilization, granting you additional land around the nearest City!
Supplies for [ICON_PRODUCTION] Production in your nearest City.
A tribe that gives you land around your nearest City.

Row.Text: [COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]Exploration[ENDCOLOR] enhances your abilties to spread your empire over the seas.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Adopting Exploration gives +1 [ICON_MOVES] Movement for Naval units and +1 Sight for Naval combat units. Unlocks building the Belem Tower.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Adopting all policies allows you to see Hidden Antiquity Sites and and allows cities to work and purchase one additional ring of tiles. It also allows the purchase of Great Admirals with [ICON_PEACE] Faith starting in the Industrial Era.
[COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]Maritime Infrastructure[ENDCOLOR][NEWLINE]+1 [ICON_PRODUCTION] Production for each Harbor, Seaport, or Lighthouse. Construct these buildings +20% faster.
[COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]Maritime Infrastructure[ENDCOLOR][NEWLINE]+1 [ICON_PRODUCTION] Production for each Drydock, Harbor, Seaport, or Lighthouse. Construct these buildings +20% faster.
[COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]Naval Tradition[ENDCOLOR][NEWLINE]+25% [ICON_PRODUCTION] Production when constructing Naval Units. Naval Units earn 33% more XP from combat.
[COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]Merchant Navy[ENDCOLOR][NEWLINE]+2 [ICON_GOLD] Gold for Internal Trade Routes. Allows establishing one additional Trade Route.
[COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]Vicegerentry[ENDCOLOR][NEWLINE]Internal Trade Routes yield 50% more [ICON_PRODUCTION] Production and [ICON_FOOD] Food. +2 [ICON_HAPPINESS_1] Happiness from each Harbor.

A vicegerent is one who acts on the behalf of a ruler or sovereign. Unlike the more typical term "viceroy," a vicegerent does not necessarily imply the representation of a monarch. In this case, a vicegerent is the agent of the state, acting on behalf of the ruler of the state, but not in the stead of the state's power.

Replace.Text: May found cities abroad, earning [ICON_GOLDEN_AGE] Golden Age Points when doing so (scales with level). +25% [ICON_STRENGTH] Combat Strength when fighting outside friendly borders.

Row.Text: Upgrades to a Great Recon Unit at level 5.
Ignores Terrain Cost and May cross mountains.
Double [ICON_MOVES] Movement through Forest, Jungle, and Marsh.
Earns XP from uncovering Fog of War and from discovering Natural Wonders.
When next to an enemy city, other units within 2 tiles get a 50% Bonus when attacking the city.

Cedar is the common name given to several similar but unrelated genera and species of evergreen trees found worldwide, each with a variety of uses which have made the trees highly prized and sought after. However, it historically has referred to just a single genus, Cedrus, native to the Mediterranean and western Himalayas. One species in particular, Cedrus libani (known commonly as the Lebanon Cedar) has been extensively used for a variety of practical and spiritual purposes since the time of the Babylonians, while their significance dates back to the earliest known civilization, having been designated as the dwelling of the gods in the Epic of Gilgamesh. The Phoenicians and Egyptians used the wood for shipbuilding, while the wood was burnt as part of Jewish celebrations of the New Year and the bark played a significant role in Hebrew cleansing ceremonies after a period of leprosy. The myriad uses of Cedar wood have not been without a toll on the population of the tree, and over the centuries the extensive use of it has resulted in the Cedar population of the Mediterranean has declined drastically. Conservation attempts have been made since the time of the Roman Emperor Hadrian, and continue to be made to this day.

Cinnamon is a spice obtained from the inner bark of several tree species from the genus Cinnamomum. Cinnamon is used mainly as an aromatic condiment and flavoring additive in a wide variety of cuisines, sweet and savoury dishes, breakfast cereals, snackfoods, and traditional foods. The aroma and flavor of cinnamon derive from its essential oil and principal component, cinnamaldehyde, as well as numerous other constituents, including eugenol.

Feathers are one of the epidermal growths that form the distinctive outer covering, or plumage, on birds and some non-avian theropod dinosaurs. They are considered the most complex integumentary structures found in vertebrates, and indeed a premier example of a complex evolutionary novelty. They are among the characteristics that distinguish the extant Aves from other living groups. Feathers have also been noticed in those Theropoda which have been termed feathered dinosaurs. Although feathers cover most parts of the body of birds, they arise only from certain well-defined tracts on the skin. They aid in flight, thermal insulation, waterproofing and coloration that helps in communication and protection.
[COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]Monopoly Bonus:[ENDCOLOR] +10% [ICON_CULTURE] Culture in all owned Cities.

Ginger is a type of root known for its distinctively hot and bitter taste, used in various traditional medicines (particularly those which claim to ease nausea) and as a spice. The plant is indigenous to China, and from there spread to the Spice Islands and other parts of Asia. As early as from the first century AD, Ginger was known to Europe as a product of the lucrative spice trade. Today, India is the largest producer of ginger.

The lotus is a type of plant native to Asia, and has a large amount of cultural significance there. For example, it is said to represent things such as sexual purity and detachment, according to Asian tradition; thus, it has a place in religion and general culture. Many Indian deities are portrayed with a lotus plant; for example, Lakshmi, Hindu goddess of love and wealth among other things, is often portrayed with a lotus to show her detachment, given the traditional representation. Lotus stamens can also be used to make green tea, which expands into Vietnamese culture as well. The fibers extracted from lotuses can also be used to make clothing, but this is only put into practice at one place: Inle Lake, in Burma, where the cloth produced is used to make special portraits of the Buddha, called “kya thingahn”, or “lotus robes” in English. Overall, the lotus has great significance within both Asian culture and religion.
[COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]Monopoly Bonus:[ENDCOLOR] +10% [ICON_PEACE] Faith in all owned Cities.

Maiz, also known as corn, is a large grain plant first domesticated by indigenous peoples in southern Mexico about 10,000 years ago. The leafy stalk of the plant produces separate pollen and ovuliferous inflorescences or ears, which are fruits, yielding kernels or seeds. Maize has become a staple food in many parts of the world, with total production surpassing that of wheat or rice. However, not all of this maize is consumed directly by humans. Some of the maize production is used for corn ethanol, animal feed and other maize products, such as corn starch and corn syrup. The six major types of corn are dent corn, flint corn, pod corn, popcorn, flour corn, and sweet corn.
Manuscripts are only available through a Mercantile City-State.

A Manuscript or Handwrit is written information that has been manually created by one or more people, such as a hand-written letter, as opposed to being printed or reproduced some other way. The term may also be used for information that is hand-recorded in other ways than writing, for example inscriptions that are chiselled upon a hard material or scratched (the original meaning of graffiti) as with a knife point in plaster or with a stylus on a waxed tablet (the way Romans made notes), or are in cuneiform writing, impressed with a pointed stylus in a flat tablet of unbaked clay.
[COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]Monopoly Bonus:[ENDCOLOR] +5% [ICON_CULTURE] Culture and +5% [ICON_PEACE] Faith in all owned Cities.

An oak is a tree or shrub in the genus Quercus, having approximately 600 extant species. The common name "Oak" may also appear in the names of species in related genera, notably Lithocarpus. The genus is native to the Northern Hemisphere, and includes deciduous and evergreen species extending from cool temperate to tropical latitudes in Asia and the Americas. North America contains the largest number of oak species, with approximately 90 occurring in the United States. Mexico has 160 species, of which 109 are endemic. The second greatest center of oak diversity is China, which contains approximately 100 species.

Obsidian is a volcanic mineral that forms when lava cools very rapidly, and with few crystals forming in the process. It is notable for being very tough, and having sharp edges on it. Obsidian has been used even before neolithic times for tools and the like; knives dating back to 700,000 BC have obsidian parts to them. By around 5000 BC, obsidian mining was present, and tools were being produced from them on a large scale. Obsidian’s sharpness made it very useful as a tool, but also as a weapon, given its sharp edges would take little sharpening for a lot of damage dealt. The substance was also used in places such as Rapa Nui for the famous Moai statues, again showing its wide application of uses. Obsidian also had a lot of trade value due to it only being found around volcanic areas. The use of obsidian declined as more refined materials, such as iron and bronze, were used for the same purpose.
[COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]Monopoly Bonus:[ENDCOLOR] Units gain +10% [ICON_STRENGTH] Strength when attacking.

A drug used for many different purposes throughout the ages, Opium has been a very valuable trading resource, acting as everything from a recreational smoking habit to a medical utility. Widespread since the dawn of civilisation, opium was used by the ancient Egyptians, Romans, Greeks and Assyrians as a painkiller, the best available one at the time. In modern medicine, opium in the form of morphine is still used for the same purpose, albeit less frequently. By the 15th century, opium became a popular recreational drug in China, though at this state it was yet to get onto the mainstream market. However, as some officials were unhappy with the use of drugs, opium began to become outlawed in China, which had a knock-on effect to the rest of the world that continued the opium trade; China was one of the main suppliers. In 1799, opium was completely banned in China, and the ban remained enforced until 1860. During this time, the British Empire became more interested in establishing a monopoly on the opium trade, managing to hold one in India after establishing control over the main opium reserves in the region. The United States were also keen to get a share, leading to a lot of market competition. As China had outlawed opium, one of the main markets for the trade was gone, forcing Britain to enter the Opium Wars, in which the British Empire soundly defeated the Qing Dynasty, and they managed to lift the opium ban in China as well as gaining Hong Kong.

Rice is a cereal grain produced primarily from plants of the Oryza genus. It serves as the staple crop for millions of people worldwide, mainly in areas of Eastern and Southern Asia and the West Indies, each group having their own preferences as to the preparation of the crop. Different regions also have different ways to grow Rice - in flatter areas of Japan and China, Rice is grown in large fields known as Rice Paddies, whereas in areas with less flat ground such as the mountainous areas of China or the Philippines, terraces are cut into the mountainside for Rice to be grown in, to support the wet conditions needed for the rice to grow.

In its native Central America and South America, rubber has been collected for a long time. The Mesoamerican civilizations used rubber mostly from Castilla elastica. The Ancient Mesoamericans had a ball game using rubber balls, and a few Pre-Columbian rubber balls have been found (always in sites that were flooded under fresh water), the earliest dating to about 1600 BC. According to Bernal Díaz del Castillo, the Spanish Conquistadores were so astounded by the vigorous bouncing of the rubber balls of the Aztecs that they wondered if the balls were enchanted by evil spirits. The Maya also made a type of temporary rubber shoe by dipping their feet into a latex mixture. Rubber was used in various other contexts, such as strips to hold stone and metal tools to wooden handles, and padding for the tool handles. While the ancient Mesoamericans did not have vulcanization, they developed organic methods of processing the rubber with similar results, mixing the raw latex with various saps and juices of other vines, particularly Ipomoea alba, a species of Morning glory. In Brazil the natives understood the use of rubber to make water-resistant cloth. A story says that the first European to return to Portugal from Brazil with samples of such water-repellent rubberized cloth so shocked people that he was brought to court on the charge of witchcraft.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]When samples of rubber first arrived in England, it was observed by Joseph Priestley, in 1770, that a piece of the material was extremely good for rubbing out pencil marks on paper.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]The para rubber tree initially grew in South America, where it was the main source of what limited amount of latex rubber was consumed during much of the 19th century. About 100 years ago, the Congo Free State in Africa was a significant source of natural rubber latex, mostly gathered by forced labor. The Congo Free State was forged and ruled as a personal colony by the Belgian King Leopold II where millions of Africans died as a result of lust for rubber and rubber profits. After repeated efforts rubber was successfully cultivated in Southeast Asia, where it is now widely grown.
[COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]Monopoly Bonus:[ENDCOLOR] +10% [ICON_PRODUCTION] Production in all owned Cities.

A type of spice that comes from its eponymous flower, the Saffron Crocus, Saffron is a resource that has been traded over thousands of years. It has major ties with the Middle East and surrounding areas, thought to have originated in Cyprus and later spread to other areas, such as Mesopotamia and later Iran, where 90% of the world’s saffron comes from today. Saffron has close ties with China, and was said to have been imported for the first time there in 500 BC; however, there are conflicting viewpoints if it was brought there by the Mongol Empire, or traded to the Chinese by the Persians. Alexander the Great was said to have made use of the saffron he picked up during his Asian campaign; he copied the Persians with some of its uses, such as using it in baths to help with wounds, and putting some on his rice.

Being abundantly available in native form, sulfur (Latin sulphur) was known in ancient times and is referred to in the Torah (Genesis). English translations of the Bible commonly referred to burning sulfur as "brimstone", giving rise to the name of 'fire-and-brimstone' sermons, in which listeners are reminded of the fate of eternal damnation that await the unbelieving and unrepentant. It is from this part of the Bible that Hell is implied to "smell of sulfur" (likely due to its association with volcanic activity). By the 3rd century, the Chinese discovered that sulfur could be extracted from pyrite. Chinese Daoists were interested in sulfur's flammability and its reactivity with certain metals, yet its earliest practical uses were found in traditional Chinese medicine. A Song Dynasty military treatise of 1044 AD described different formulas for Chinese black powder, which is a mixture of potassium nitrate (KNO3), charcoal, and sulfur.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Early alchemists gave sulfur its own alchemical symbol which was a triangle at the top of a cross. In traditional medical skin treatment which predates modern era of scientific medicine, elemental sulfur has been used mainly as part of creams to alleviate various conditions such as scabies, ringworm, psoriasis, eczema and acne. The mechanism of action is not known, although elemental sulfur does oxidize slowly to sulfurous acid, which in turn (through the action of sulfite) acts as a mild reducing and antibacterial agent.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]In 1777, Antoine Lavoisier helped convince the scientific community that sulfur was an element, not a compound. With the sulfur from Sicily being principally controlled by the French market, a debate ensued about the amount of sulfur France and Britain got. This led to a bloodless confrontation between the two sides in 1840. In 1867, sulfur was discovered in underground deposits in Louisiana and Texas. The highly successful Frasch process was developed to extract this resource. With the advent of the contact process, the majority of sulfur today is used to make sulfuric acid for a wide range of uses, particularly fertilizer.

Vanilla is a flavoring derived from orchids of the genus Vanilla, primarily from the Mexican species, flat-leaved vanilla. Pre-Columbian Mesoamerican peoples cultivated the vine of the vanilla orchid, called tlilxochitl by the Aztecs, and Spanish conquistador Hernan Cortez is credited with introducing both vanilla and chocolate to Europe in the 1520s.[NEWLINE][TAB]The Totonac people, who inhabit the Mazatlan Valley on the Gulf Coast of Mexico in the present-day state of Veracruz, were the first to cultivate vanilla. According to Totonac mythology, the tropical orchid was born when Princess Xanat, forbidden by her father from marrying a mortal, fled to the forest with her lover. The lovers were captured and beheaded. Where their blood touched the ground, the vine of the tropical orchid grew. In the 15th century, Aztecs invading from the central highlands of Mexico conquered the Totonacs, and soon developed a taste for the vanilla pods. They named the fruit tlilxochitl, or "black flower", after the matured fruit, which shrivels and turns black shortly after it is picked. Subjugated by the Aztecs, the Totonacs paid tribute by sending vanilla fruit to the Aztec capital, Tenochtitlan.
+1 [ICON_FOOD] Food, +2 [ICON_CULTURE] Culture from Maize, Rice, and Wheat.

Replace.Text: Embarking or disembarking in owned cities expends just 1 [ICON_MOVES] Movement.
Embarkingor disembarking in owned cities expends 0 [ICON_MOVES] Movement.

Row.Text: Units ignore terrain costs when moving into any tile with Hills. Improvements cost half maintenance, and no maintenance if in hills. Units may move and settle on Mountains and, when settling on Mountains, provide a free Mint in the city.
Superior at exploring over the Explorer, this unit is not slowed by rough terrain, but is vulnerable to attack.
This late-game unit can attack but is weak. However, it can move through difficult terrain as though it were clear (all tiles cost 1mp per hex). Use it for world exploration.

Although the coasts of Africa had been explored for three centuries, it was not until the early 19th Century AD that the European powers began a concerted effort to explore the hinterlands of the continent. Beginning from coastal trading posts, missions and colonial settlements, Western explorers pushed inland in small expeditions seeking legendary wonders, "lost" native civilizations, and scientific knowledge. Some, like David Livingston, were medical missionaries; some, like Pietro di Brazza, sought adventure; and others, such as MacGregor Laird, were merchants seeking new opportunities for profit. Whatever their motivations, the European explorers figure prominently in the history of Africa.
Superior at exploring over the Adventurer, this unit is not slowed by rough terrain, but is vulnerable to attack.

This late-game unit can attack but is weak. However, it can move through difficult terrain as though it were clear (all tiles cost 1mp per hex). Use it for world exploration. After reaching level 5, this unit automatically becomes a Great Reconnaissance Unit, which has enhanced abilities.

An airship is a type of aircraft that is lighter-than-air and that can be propelled by using rudders and propellers. Today, all modern airships use the non-flammable gas, helium, in order to sustain flight, where once the use of flammable hydrogen was common.
Superior at exploring over the Scout, this unit is not slowed by rough terrain, but is vulnerable to attack.
This mid-game unit can attack but is weak. However, it can move through difficult terrain as though it were clear (all tiles cost 1mp per hex). Use it for world exploration.

Exploration is the act of searching or traveling around a terrain (including space, see space exploration) for the purpose of discovery of resources or information. Exploration occurs in all non-sessile animal species, including humans. In human history, its peak is arguably seen during the Age of Discovery for Europe's contact with the rest of the world, and major explorations after the Age of Discovery for scientific exploration in the modern era.
Excellent at exploring, this Unit is not slowed by rough terrain, but is vulnerable to attack.
This early-game unit can attack but is weak. However, it can move through difficult terrain as though it were clear (all tiles cost 1mp per hex). Use it for world exploration.

Requires Exploration. A Great Admiral appears near the city where the Belem Tower is built. Land Units trained in this city have [ICON_STRENGTH] Defense and +1 Sight whilst embarked.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]City must be built on coast.

Requires Exploration. Two free Explorers appears near the city where the Belem Tower is built. Land Units trained in this city have [ICON_STRENGTH] Defense and +1 Sight whilst embarked.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]City must be built on coast.

Requires Exploration. A Great Explorer appears near the city where the Belem Tower is built. Land Units trained in this city have [ICON_STRENGTH] Defense and +1 Sight whilst embarked.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]City must be built on coast.
[NEWLINE]"And the sea will grant each man new hope . . . his sleep brings dreams of home"[NEWLINE] - Christopher Columbus[NEWLINE]

The Belém Tower sits at the mouth of the Tagus River, just outside the city of Lisbon. The idea of the tower came from João II, though he died before planning or building could start. His successor, Manuel I, instead designed and built the tower. Unusually, it was built on a small island as a sort of sea fort, intended to be a defence mechanism for Lisbon’s potentially vulnerable coast. However, there is a popular belief that the tower was initially built inland, but shifted out to sea by the Great Lisbon Earthquake. The building was completed in 1519, and over the coming years, it was improved and strengthened to be more effective against potential attacks. However, the Belém Tower is perhaps best known for its role in the Portuguese Renaissance - or, more specifically, an icon of the colonisation of the New World. As an island fortress, just outside the shipbuilding hub of Portugal, the Belém Tower would have been the last sight that ships going on their maiden voyage would have seen. In later years, the tower also took up the role of a customs house that ships were required to pay tax to, and the main navigation lookout of Lisbon. Over the years, it also served as a military garrison, given its capabilities as a coastal garrison. Today, the Belém Tower is a popular tourist destination, as not only does it have a long history, but architecture considered to be among the best examples of the Manueline style, a late gothic Portuguese building form.
1 free Great Artist appears near the City where the Wonder was built. Contains 4 slots for Great Works of Art.
